newsitem.title: USA: Workgroup Q2 revs may fall, could take loss.
newsitem.headline: Workgroup Q2 revs may fall, could take loss.

text.p: Workgroup Technology Corp said Friday that it expects revenues for the second quarter 1996 to be below analysts' estimates and that the shortfall could result in a net loss for the quarter.

The company added that it expects revenue for the remaining quarters of the fiscal year to be below analysts' projections. Workgroup said in a statement that additional expenses related to the formation of a new development unit, along with the decrease in revenue, could result in net losses for the third and fourth quarters of the fiscal year as well.

Workgroup used analysts from Alex Brown & Sons Inc, Wessels, Arnold & Henderson, and Robertson, Stephens & Co to project revenue estimates for the second quarter ending September 30, 1996 and for the remaining quarters of the fiscal year ending March 31, 1997.
An analyst from Alex Brown said he had lowered his revenue estimate for the year to $13.5 million from $17 million and decreased earnings per share to $0.06 from $0.28.
Workgroup reported first quarter 1996 results of $3.47 million in total revenues with a net income of $881,000, or $0.10 per share.
President and CEO James Carney cited three reasons for the "potential revenue shortfall."

"Our European operations, which were started last year, are anticipated to produce revenue levels less than what we had planned," Carney said in the release, citing weaknesses in the European economy and a "less mature" market for the company's products and services.

Carney also said delivery of an NT version of the company's server product has been delayed until the fourth quarter, and that Workgroup is experiencing "slippage in the timing of the closing of several significant orders."
